label.text: Pteropod Shells
Carbon dioxide (CO₂) dissolves in seawater to form carbonic acid. This process is known as ocean acidification.
In an ocean field study, scientists investigated the effect of ocean acidification on the shells of pteropods (planktonic snails). The snails use calcium carbonate from water to form their shells.
The scientists collected pteropods and several water samples from different sites. They then examined the shells for small holes called pits.
pits
pteropod shell
The scientists collected water samples from each site and determined if the sample was saturated or undersaturated with calcium carbonate (the solute).
Water is ‘saturated’ if the maximum amount of a solute is dissolved in it. Water is 'undersaturated' if it contains less than the maximum amount of dissolved solute.

The graph plots the percentage of shells with severe pitting as a function of the percentage of water samples that were undersaturated with calcium carbonate at each site. Each cross represents a different site.

text.strong: Percentage of shells with severe pitting at each site
Percentage of water samples that were undersaturated at each site

label.text: The scientists think that more pitting occurred in more acidic seawater.
If the scientists are correct, which of the following statements must be true?
Use the graph to answer the question.
The undersaturated water samples were more acidic than the saturated water samples.
Carbonic acid causes shells to dissolve but other acids do not.
Pitting of the shells has only occurred since CO₂ levels have increased.
Mechanical damage does not cause shells to become pitted.
A website author claimed that the results of this study showed that, “Ocean acidification causes changes to pteropod shells.”
Is this claim supported by the data from the graph?
Select ‘Yes’ or ‘No’.
Yes
No
Explain your answer by referring to the graph.
Scientists collected undamaged pteropod shells.
They placed half of them in a tank containing a saturated water solution, and the other half in a tank containing an undersaturated water solution. All other variables were kept constant.
They prepared the laboratory experiment according to the figure below.
Apart from differing calcium carbonate saturation, the tanks contained equal amounts of other salts so that the water resembled seawater.
tank containing water saturated with calcium carbonate
pteropods
tank containing water undersaturated with calcium carbonate
distilled water with calcium carbonate and other salts
After some time, they examined the shells of the pteropods in the tanks.

text.strong: Can the following questions be answered by this laboratory experiment, or by the ocean field study, or both?

label.text: Select ‘Yes’ or ‘No’ for each dropdown menu.
Question
Laboratory experiment
Ocean field study
Do pteropod shells dissolve in seawater?
Yes
No
Do pteropod shells dissolve in undersaturated water?
Does undersaturated water cause shells to dissolve?
Does temperature affect the rate that shells dissolve?
